xxl.core.cursors.sources
Class ContinuousRandomNumber

java.lang.Object
  xxl.core.cursors.AbstractCursor<Double>
      xxl.core.cursors.sources.ContinuousRandomNumber
All Implemented Interfaces:
Iterator<Double>, Cursor<Double>
public class ContinuousRandomNumber
extends AbstractCursor<Double>

A cursor providing a finite or infinite stream of randomly distributed double values given by the wrapped pseudo random number generator for continuous numbers. XXL provides two kinds of PRNG, namley, the first based on Java's random number generator and the second based on Colt's random number generator (cern.jet.random.AbstractContinousDistribution).

Example usage (1): 

     ContinuousRandomNumber crn = new ContinuousRandomNumber(
         new JavaContinuousRandomWrapper(),
         200
     );
 
     crn.open();
 
     long i = 0;
     while (crn.hasNext())
         System.out.println((i++) + "\t:\t" + crn.next());
     System.out.println();
 
     crn.close();
This example produces a finite stream of randomly distributed double values delivered by a PRNG, i.e., Java's random number generator is used for the provision of randomly distributed double values. The returned stream of integer objects contains 200 elements as specified in the constructor.

See Also:
Iterator, Cursor, AbstractCursor, Random

Constructor Detail

ContinuousRandomNumber

public ContinuousRandomNumber(ContinuousRandomWrapper continuousRandomWrapper,
                              long numberOfElements)
Constructs a new continuous random number cursor delivering randomly distributed continuous numbers (double values). If the given number of elements is greater than or equal to 0 the cursor provides a finite number of elements otherwise an infinite number of elements is provided.

Parameters:
continuousRandomWrapper - the random number generator wrapper to be used for the provision of random double values.
numberOfElements - the number of elements to be returned. If the given number is greater than or equal to 0 the cursor provides a finite number of elements otherwise an infinite number of elements is provided.

ContinuousRandomNumber

public ContinuousRandomNumber(ContinuousRandomWrapper continuousRandomWrapper)
Constructs a new continuous random number cursor delivering an infinite number of randomly distributed continuous numbers (double values).

Parameters:
continuousRandomWrapper - the random number generator wrapper to be used for the provision of random double values.

ContinuousRandomNumber

public ContinuousRandomNumber(long numberOfElements)
Constructs a new continuous random number cursor delivering randomly distributed continuous numbers (double values). If the given number of elements is greater than or equal to 0 the cursor provides a finite number of elements otherwise an infinite number of elements is provided. Java's random number generator is is used for the provision of random double values.

Parameters:
numberOfElements - the number of elements to be returned. If the given number is greater than or equal to 0 the cursor provides a finite number of elements otherwise an infinite number of elements is provided.

ContinuousRandomNumber

public ContinuousRandomNumber()
Constructs a new continuous random number cursor delivering an infinite number of randomly distributed continuous numbers (double values). Java's random number generator is is used for the provision of random double values.

Method Detail

hasNextObject

protected boolean hasNextObject()
Returns true if the iteration has more elements. (In other words, returns true if next or peek would return an element rather than throwing an exception.)

Specified by:
hasNextObject in class AbstractCursor<Double>
Returns:
true if the continuous random number cursor has more elements.

nextObject

protected Double nextObject()
Returns the next element in the iteration. This element will be accessible by some of the continuous random number cursor's methods, e.g., update or remove, until a call to next or peek occurs. This is calling next or peek proceeds the iteration and therefore its previous element will not be accessible any more.

Specified by:
nextObject in class AbstractCursor<Double>
Returns:
the next element in the iteration.

reset

public void reset()
Resets the continuous random number cursor to its initial state such that the caller is able to traverse the iteration again without constructing a new continuous random number cursor (optional operation).

Note, that this operation is optional and might not work for all cursors.

Specified by:
reset in interface Cursor<Double>
Overrides:
reset in class AbstractCursor<Double>
Throws:
UnsupportedOperationException - if the reset operation is not supported by the continuous random number cursor.

supportsReset

public boolean supportsReset()
Returns true if the reset operation is supported by the continuous random number cursor. Otherwise it returns false.

Specified by:
supportsReset in interface Cursor<Double>
Overrides:
supportsReset in class AbstractCursor<Double>
Returns:
true if the reset operation is supported by the continuous random number cursor, otherwise false.

main

The main method contains some examples to demonstrate the usage and the functionality of this class.

Parameters:
args - array of String arguments. It can be used to submit parameters when the main method is called.
